Hi, We're seeing an issue where fields are suddenly not returning from the API. The first array is the field keys that were returning fine as of Wednesday of this week. Many of these are custom properties, but `name` is a core property of the Company Object, obvs. The second is an actual response when all of these fields have been requested on the response object. There's been no code changes that would explain this on our end. Anyone having similar?

Hi everyone! I'm not sure I chose the right channel so feel free to redirect :slightly_smiling_face:
We want to track visitors activity on our website and have already added HubSpot Embed Tracking Code and now we are trying to deal with Tracking Code API. Could somebody please tell me what should I add in our code to make it work properly?
How can I use a this construction to track visitors?
`var _hsq = window._hsq = window._hsq || [];` 
`let urlPath = String(window.location.pathname) ;` 
 `_hsq.push(['setPath', urlPath]);` 

Should I add smth like this on each page ?
`var _hsq = window._hsq = window._hsq || []; _hsq.push(['setPath', '/pricing/']);` 

Thanks in advance.

reposting this lol: Curious if anyone wants to dive into their process for scoping out and pricing API integrations where you are connecting to unknown systems. I feel like I always underscope the hell out of these and then hate myself when projects drag on for an additional 2-3 weeks and I’m just bleeding time and money
I just multiply by 3x the time. :joy:
That would put me in a much better place!
thanks for resurrecting your post.
I was wrapping up the integration until 2am last night and was like WHY DO I DO THIS TO MYSELF
I've been there many times
I also try and get the company to give me a postman of their apis
Usually it helps keep project on track.
I feel like I get api jobs that have no documentation and xml apis with the most random authenitcation method
<https://gist.github.com/NickDeckerDevs/12f670ddf51f25a66b1f0d98e90370d6>
Yes! authenticate sent through the body of the request
and then they give like java code, and being self taught I’ve used very little java, everything was so verbose I just disliked it
the postman idea is pretty legit
Haven't used Java in like 6 years so I just turn and run if they want java
You can get Nodejs, Deno, Vanilla JS, or some other language but please no PHP and definitely no Java
lol I started php 3 — I try to avoid as much as posisble but I do work in it still. I just stick to js at this point. some .net as well, probably more php then .net

"The scope needed for this API call isn't available for public use. If you have questions, contact support or post in our developer forum."

To quote an old friend on estimating software (and I think it is mostly true when using 3rd party apis etc.) take your estimate, double it and go to the next unit. So if it should take a week, plan 2 months. :slightly_smiling_face:
So 1 month is 2 years?
go to the next unit? what does that mean
Days => Weeks, Weeks => Months, Months => Years, Years => Decades
AHH
time isn’t real like birds
so I didn’t get the concept

The <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/crm/contacts|Contacts API documentation> mentions a 10-input batch operation limit:
>  Batch operations for creating, updating, and archiving are limited to batches of 10.
There isn’t equivalent documentation for the other CRM object types.

Does the 10-item batch limit apply to _all_ CRM batch operations, or does it just for contacts?
Found the answer: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/APIs-Integrations/Batch-Limit-for-Batch-Endpoints/m-p/401309>
